I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  the  institutional 
strengthening of the national statistical system (NSS) of Myanmar in collaboration with the Central 
Statistical Organization (CSO) and the Planning Department of the Ministry of Planning and 
Finance of Myanmar.1 The TA will build on the achievements of an earlier Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  project—Technical  Assistance  for  Myanmar  for  Capacity  Development  of  the 
National Statistical System—financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and completed 
in June 2019.2 
 
2.  The TA is included in the approved 2019 work plan of ADB’s Economic Research and 
Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) and supports one of the five priority themes of ADB’s 
country partnership strategy (CPS) 2017–2021 for Myanmar—the capacity and governance 
theme, which aims to accelerate the country’s transformation process by intensifying its focus on 
capacity development and governance.3 The TA also supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 Operational 
Plans: Operational Priority 6: Strengthening Governance and Institutional Capacity, 2019–2024, 
which states that building strong statistical institutions to improve availability of timely and reliable 
statistics is essential for informed decision-making and inclusive development; and is aligned with 
the Global Action Plan for Sustainable Development Data through target 17.19 of the Sustainable 
Development Goals, which aims to support initiatives for measuring progress on sustainable 
development and statistical capacity building in developing countries. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ADB identified capacity and governance as one of the development challenges related to 
its reengagement with Myanmar in 2012. For a country in transition to a market economy like 
Myanmar, capacity development that will accelerate its transformation process is crucial in 
supporting the government’s policy priority of improving the quality of life of its people. Myanmar’s 
economic  vision  is  to  achieve  inclusive  and  sustainable  economic  development,  and  the 
government has committed to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and tracking the 
progress through a set of measurable indicators. ADB’s CPS 2017−2021 indicates that the 
capacity of the public sector is underdeveloped and poses a significant challenge to basic service 
delivery. The CPS further underlines the importance of statistics to the development of Myanmar, 
specifically indicating that “the quality, timeliness, and accessibility of Myanmar’s economic and 
social statistics, while improving with ongoing development support, remain poor and constrained 
by weak institutional and human capacity.” Capacity development and governance, a priority 
theme of the CPS, support evidence-based reforms and planning, not least the strengthening of 
national statistics and analytical capacity. With assistance from ADB and other development 
partners, the ability of Myanmar’s NSS to produce quality and timely statistics has been improving, 
but much room remains for long-term and sustained support to strengthen institutions, upgrade 
their standards and methods so as to improve data quality and accessibility, and build statistical 
infrastructure and human capacity.   
 
 
1   A knowledge and support TA may be used for capacity development, policy advice, and research and development. 
The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 18 November 2019. 
2  ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance to Myanmar for Capacity Development of the National Statistical System. Manila 
(TA 8377). 
3  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Myanmar, 2017−2021⎯Building the Foundations for Inclusive Growth. 
Manila.

2 
4.  The Statistics and Data Innovation Unit of the ERCD (EROD-SDI)4 was engaged with 
strengthening Myanmar’s NSS through phase 1 of the TA implemented from June 2013 to June 
2019 (footnote 2). Through that TA phase, ADB comprehensively assessed the institutional and 
legal aspects of Myanmar’s NSS; provided extensive inputs to the preparation of the National 
Strategy for Development of Statistics (NSDS); drafted a new statistics law for Myanmar to replace 
the outdated Statistics Act of 1952 (the Parliament of Myanmar promulgated the new Statistics 
Law of 2018 in January 2018); drafted statistics rules for implementing the Statistics Law of 2018; 
assessed the system of national accounts statistics of Myanmar and drafted a strategy for 
adopting the latest standards—the System of National Accounts 2008 (2008 SNA); provided TA 
and built the capacity for adopting the 2008 SNA framework for the compilation of national 
accounts statistics; provided support for developing a statistical business register (SBR) in the 
CSO; built the internal training capacity of the CSO; and supported several internal and external 
training programs to build the skills of staff of the CSO, Planning Department, and line ministries.  
 
5.  More is needed to expand national data sets and improve the quality and timeliness of 
data for monitoring government programs and to support evidence-based policies to achieve 
inclusive and sustainable development. The CSO prepared the Implementation Plan of the 
National Strategy for Development of Statistics (NSDS-IP) to steer statistical production toward 
meeting users’ data needs.5 It sets out eight strategies to bring about systematic improvements 
in the NSS and to improve subject matter programs and methodologies. A key lesson from the 
phase 1 TA and from the implementation of the interim CPS for 2012−2014 for Myanmar was that 
sustainable capacity building is a gradual and long-term process, which should evolve from 
project-specific approaches to sector- and country-system development activities.6 This implies 
that the efforts that were started under the phase 1 TA and even under the TA projects of other 
development partners in Myanmar must be sustained for Myanmar’s NSS to continue going up 
the ladder of sustainable statistical development. Hence, the phase 2 TA will further build on the 
achievements of the phase 1 TA, and is aligned with four of the eight strategic priorities outlined 
in the NSDS-IP—i.e., improvements in the legal and organizational infrastructure, in the statistical 
infrastructure, in human resource capacity, and in economic statistics. These are also broadly the 
strategic areas for which the CSO and the Planning Department received phase 1 support and 
where they have expressed interest for continuing ADB support. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: The ability of the NSS of Myanmar to support 
evidence-based policymaking and monitor the achievement of development targets improved.7 
The TA will have the following outcome: institutional and technical capacity of the NSS of 
Myanmar for producing timely and quality statistics strengthened.8 
 
 
4  ERCD’s realignment in January 2019 led to the creation of EROD-SDI, which consists of the statistics group of the 
erstwhile Development Economics and Indicators Division.  
5  CSO, recognized as the national statistical agency under the Statistics Law 2018, formulated the NSDS with support 
from the World Bank and in collaboration with ADB and other development partners. TA 8377 (footnote 2) provided 
extensive inputs and recommendations for the development of the NSDS. The NSDS-IP for 2018–19 to 2022–23 
provides strategic directions and actions for implementing the NSDS and is also a valuable coordination mechanism 
for development partners in supporting national priorities for strengthening capacity of Myanmar’s NSS. 
6  ADB. 2012. Interim Country Partnership Strategy: Myanmar, 2012−2014. Manila. 
7  CSO. 2016. National Strategy for Development of Statistics. Nay Pyi Taw. 
8  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.   Output 1: Instruments of the institutional and legal capacity of Myanmar’s national 
statistical system strengthened. In the context of the newly adopted Statistics Law 2018 and 
the draft statistics rules supported under the phase 1 TA, the TA team will support the CSO in 
finalizing and approving the statistics rules and their implementation. It will provide technical 
support to the CSO for initiating actions that will strengthen its role of leading the NSS, as 
mandated  under  the  Statistics  Law,  and  for  creating  awareness  and  understanding  of  its 
provisions on the roles and responsibilities of stakeholders.  
 
8.  Output 2: Central Statistical Organization and Planning Department management 
capacity strengthened. Expert engaged through the TA will provide advisory services to the 
CSO management to support its role as secretariat of the Central Committee for Data Accuracy 
and Quality of Statistics. This involves policies and actions needed for managing and coordinating 
national statistical operations, coordinating with development partners and stakeholders, and 
implementing the provisions of the statistics rules. The TA team will also organize learning 
missions  for  CSO  and  Planning  Department  to  neighboring  countries  with  well-developed 
statistical systems to harness good management and coordination practices, including data 
dissemination and adoption of technology in modernizing statistical systems.9 
 
9.  Output 3: Compilation of national accounts statistics of Myanmar based on the 
framework of the 2008 System of National Accounts improved. The TA will build on the 
progress of the phase 1 TA in implementing the 2008 SNA framework and assist the Planning 
Department in further improving the national accounts statistics and methodology. The TA will 
support rebasing10 of the national accounts series following the 2008 SNA framework to the extent 
permitted by available data sources and producing supply-use tables for a benchmark year, 
documentation and publishing of sources and methods, and release and revision of annual 
national accounts estimates. The TA will support learning from the proven good practices and 
systems of other developing countries in producing national accounts statistics. 
 
10.  Output 4: Human resources and technical skills improved. The phase 1 TA built a 
good foundation for the internal training capacity of the CSO and supported various training 
programs for newly recruited and existing staff of the CSO and some line ministries. The TA team 
will continue to strengthen the CSO’s internal training capacity to enable it to effectively perform 
its role as the training provider for staff in the CSO and line ministries. It will conduct in-country 
training in specialized areas of official statistics with direct application to the compilation of official 
statistics and for the modernization of statistical processes. To professionalize the statistician 
career in Myanmar, the TA will also support external short- and long-term training, including 
higher-level formal statistics education in coordination with centers of excellence.11 The CSO’s 
training room also needs upgrading, and  the TA will provide limited support for the purchase of

Philippines, and these candidates now occupy leadership positions in Cambodia’s National Institute of Statistics.

computers, software, and other equipment for the smooth conduct of training activities. Moreover, 
the TA team will explore ways for staff to learn some specific technical skills through staff 
exchange programs with other national statistics offices. 
 
11.  Output 5: Statistical infrastructure strengthened through continued development of 
the statistical business register and of classifications and standards. An SBR is useful in 
the production of business statistics and also serves as sampling frame for business surveys, 
which are essential inputs for key economic statistics such as national accounts statistics. They 
provide better understanding of the business landscape (across all industries and business sizes) 
of an economy. The phase 1 TA prepared the ground by setting up the ADB SBR system in the 
CSO.12 To sustain that system, the TA team will support technical improvements and build the 
technical capacity of the CSO’s SBR team for updating and maintaining the SBR. Finally, the TA 
will support the finalization of the Myanmar version of the International Standard Industrial 
Classification in line with the classification needs of the Myanmar economy.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2.  
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, logistics and administrative support, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The Ministry of Planning and Finance will be the executing agency, while the CSO and 
the Planning Department will be the implementing agencies. ADB will administer the TA through 
EROD-SDI. ADB will recruit international and national consultants through individual consultant 
selection and carry out procurement activities (paras. 16 and 17). ADB will select, supervise, and 
evaluate the consultants; procure goods; organize workshops; and provide staff to act as resource 
persons in the workshops.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to the 
Republic of the Union of Myanmar for Capacity Development of the National Statistical System 
(Phase 2), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.    Instruments of the institutional and legal capacity of Myanmar’s national statistical system strengthened 
1.1  Engage international and national consultants (January–March 2020) 
1.2  Assess the CSO’s status and needs in relation to its role in the new Statistics Law and Rules and the NSDS 
(February–April 2020) 
1.3  Prepare a plan of action to finalize the implementing rules and regulations (February–April 2020) 
1.4  Finalize the implementing rules and regulations (April–June 2020) 
1.5  Conduct awareness-raising workshops to increase system-wide awareness and advocacy of the Statistics Law 
and Rules (with support from the statistics advisor engaged by ADB) (July–December 2021) 
2.    Central Statistical Organization and Planning Department management capacity strengthened 
2.1  Recruit international statistics advisor to guide CSO and Planning Department management (January–March 
2020) 
2.2. Discuss with the CSO management the workflow and work arrangements between the advisor and CSO 
management, and refine the agreement on the advisor’s terms of reference (April 2020) 
2.3  Provide advisory services for managing the NSS, sharing data, disseminating data, and implementing ADB TA 
activities under all components in collaboration with the activities of other development partners  
3.  Compilation of national accounts statistics of Myanmar based on the framework of the 2008 System of 
National Accounts improved 
3.1  Assess the status of readiness, outline methodology, data sources, and plan of action with detailed activities 
and timelines for rebasing of national accounts series following the 2008 SNA framework, including the role of 
the National Accounts Statistics Cluster formed under the NSDS (January–April 2020) 
3.2  Discuss methodology, data sources, and action plan in a workshop with the Planning Department and National 
Accounts Statistics Cluster group (March–April 2020) 
3.3  Implement the action plan by the Planning Department for rebasing of national accounts series with ADB 
technical support, and collaborate with data source agencies (May 2020–June 2021) 
3.4  Draft technical documents on sources, methods, and results of rebased series for compiling national accounts of 
Myanmar, and stakeholder consultations (July–December 2021) 
3.5  Integrate stakeholder feedback, finalize, and disseminate the new rebased data series by the Planning 
Department (January–June 2022) 
3.6  Identify areas for future improvements (April–June 2022) 
4.    Human resources and technical skills improved 
4.1  Explore appropriate external training and exchange programs for the CSO and ministries (February–April 2020) 
4.2  Draft eligibility, selection criteria, and conditionalities for acceptance of participants (March 2020) 
4.3  Call for participants in the external training programs and exchange programs (April 2020–December 2021) 
4.4  Send selected staff to external training and exchange programs (July 2020–June 2022)  
4.5  Conduct internal training for basic, intermediate, and advanced or specialized topics including training for 
trainers (April 2020–December 2022) 
5.    Statistical infrastructure through continued development of the statistical business register and 
classifications and standards strengthened 
5.1  Facilitate improvements to the system, e.g., localization of the system interface, customization of the system, 
improvements to other functionalities, expanded coverage and updates of businesses’ data, export of sampling 
frames (March–December 2020) 
5.2  Provide continued technical and capacity building onsite and offsite to support system maintenance (March 
2020–June 2020) 
5.3  Conduct meetings and workshops for finalizing the MSIC (April 2020–June 2021) 
5.4  Revise the draft MSIC (October 2020–June 2021)
